column2: In a letter to Steve Jobs, Sean Connery refused to appear in an apple commercial.
column5: There is no evidence to support the claim that Sean Connery wrote a letter to Steve Jobs refusing to appear in an Apple commercial. Instead, the letter in question was revealed to be a [satire piece](https://www.cnet.com/culture/fake-sean-connery-letter-to-steve-jobs-goes-viral/) from a humor website and not an actual communication from Connery to Jobs. Multiple credible sources, including [Snopes](https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/false-sean-connery-letter-to-apple/) and [CNET](https://www.cnet.com/culture/fake-sean-connery-letter-to-steve-jobs-goes-viral/), confirm that the story originated from a satirical website called Scoopertino, which fabricated the entire scenario as part of a humorous article.
column7: The answer and sources show that the claim was published in a fake news site so the claim is refuted.

While the authenticity of the documents can't be fully verified, top-ranking Democrats referenced them, lending credibility to their existence. Notably, the language used in the leaked documents seems inconsistent with the Trump Administration's previous rhetoric and policy positions towards the music industry.

column2: UNESCO declared Nadar community as the most ancient race in the world.
column5: The claim that UNESCO declared the Nadar community as the most ancient race in the world is refuted due to lack of evidence. Despite being a real ethnic or social group with a documented history, there is no record of UNESCO making such a declaration, nor is it supported by official UNESCO documents, expert opinions, or credible news sources. In fact, UNESCO rejects the idea of declaring certain communities as the "most ancient" races in the world, emphasizing the unity of humanity and rejecting notions of inherent superiority based on ethnicity or nationality [http://www.honestthinking.org/en/unesco/UNESCO.1950.Statement_on_Race.htm](http://www.honestthinking.org/en/unesco/UNESCO.1950.Statement_on_Race.htm).
column7: This claim is refuted. According to the QA pairs, UNESCO have never declared a "most ancient race", and for those who have analysed this question, they have theorised that the San people of southern Africa may be the most "ancient race"- no the Nadar community. Therefore, this claim is refuted.

column2: You’re watching the cheaters and all those people that send in the phony ballots. … They want to have the count weeks after November 3.
column5:
Donald Trump's claim that people are sending in phony ballots and wanting to delay the count until weeks after November 3rd is refuted. Despite his assertions, there is no concrete evidence of widespread voter fraud involving mail-in ballots [1]. In fact, experts and government investigations have consistently found little to no evidence of significant voter fraud [1][2]. Furthermore, states have mechanisms in place to verify the authenticity of mail-in ballots before counting them [7], and while there have been isolated incidents of voter fraud, these are extremely rare [2][6]. The claim also ignores the reality of the 2020 presidential election, where several states changed their mail-in balloting procedures or regulations due to the COVID-19 pandemic [10].

column2: New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening
column5:
The claim that New Zealand's new Food Bill bans gardening is entirely unfounded. A thorough review of the Food Act 2014 reveals no explicit mentions of restrictions or prohibitions on personal gardening activities [1]. In fact, individuals can still grow their own fruits and vegetables for personal consumption under the current regulations outlined in the Food Bill [2]. No reputable news sources or agricultural organizations reported on the alleged gardening ban, and local authorities or law enforcement agencies in New Zealand did not indicate how they will enforce a supposed gardening ban, as no such ban seems to exist [3][4].

column2: Wearing face masks will stop the spread of covid 19
column5: The verdict is supported because multiple peer-reviewed studies demonstrate a statistically significant reduction in COVID-19 cases directly attributed to widespread face mask usage ([PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32543923/)). Public health organizations such as the [World Health Organization (WHO)](https://verafiles.org/articles/vera-files-fact-sheet-ang-mga-maling-palagay-sa-face-mask-in-2) and [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)](https://verafiles.org/articles/vera-files-fact-sheet-ang-mga-maling-palagay-sa-face-mask-in-2) recommend face masks as a primary method to prevent COVID-19 transmission. Real-world examples show that mandatory face mask policies have led to a significant decline in COVID-19 cases. While face masks alone may not be enough to completely eliminate the risk of transmission, the evidence strongly suggests that they play a crucial role in reducing the spread of COVID-19 when used in combination with other measures like social distancing and hand hygiene.
column7: From the question and answer pair it does indeed seem that face masks are useful in stopping the spread of covid19. Therefore, the claim is supported.

column2: Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) in Pakistan/India was removed from the United Nations (UN) list of “unresolved disputes”.

Without sufficient evidence, the claim cannot be supported. [Source](https://www.un.org/en/library/unms).

While there are signs of reductions in illegal activities, analysts suggest that smugglers adapt to physical barriers, and other factors like changed policing strategies, resource allocation, and legislation also contribute to the complex issue. column2: The plentiful evidence we have indicates that masks would not meaningfully help with aerosol transmission of COVID 19.
column5: The claim that masks do not meaningfully help with aerosol transmission of COVID-19 is refuted. Despite the lack of supporting evidence from the claimant, numerous peer-reviewed journal articles, expert opinions, and guidelines from reputable health organizations like [World Health Organization](https://www.vox.com/2020/6/6/21282108/masks-for-covid-19-world-health-organization-guidelines-cloth-n95) and [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](https://www.cdc.gov/) confirm that masks can significantly reduce the transmission of COVID-19. Studies estimate that mask-wearing reduces transmission rates by varying degrees, depending on factors such as compliance, mask quality, and environmental conditions ([preprints.org](https://www.preprints.org/manuscript/202004.0203/v2)). The scientific consensus is clear: masks are an effective measure in reducing aerosol transmission of COVID-19.
column7: Evidence finds that surgical face masks could prevent transmission of human coronaviruses and influenza viruses from symptomatic individuals. The CDC and the World Health Organization (WHO), at the time of the claim, also recommended cloth masks for the general public.

column2: All USA Ballots Arriving After Election Day Will Be Thrown Out
column5: The Claim "All USA Ballots Arriving After Election Day Will Be Thrown Out" is refuted because there is no federal law mandating this, individual states have their own laws and regulations, and there have been instances where ballots arriving after Election Day were accepted and counted in previous US elections [1](https://www.votewalton.com/Voting/Ways-to-Vote). High courts, including the Supreme Court, have also ruled on similar cases, showing that the issue is not always straightforward [2](https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-samuel-alito-amy-coney-barrett-north-carolina-elections-4cb4c214446bcfadbd73dafca9353701). Overall, the Claim oversimplifies the complexities of electoral laws and regulations across the United States.
column7: Two sources confirm that postal ballots received after election day can still be counted, therefore not all will be thrown out.

column2: Even if your mail-in ballot is postmarked prior to the Election day but arrives after the Election day it will be thrown out.
column5: The claim that mail-in ballots postmarked prior to Election Day but arriving after will always be thrown out is refuted because individual states have varying laws and regulations governing mail-in ballots, with some accepting ballots postmarked by Election Day and arriving within a specified timeframe afterwards ([California](https://www.democracydocket.com/analysis/mailing-in-your-vote-important-dates/) and [Illinois](https://chicagoelections.gov/voting/vote-mail)) and others discarding those arriving after Election Day despite earlier postmarks ([Michigan](https://www.democracydocket.com/analysis/mailing-in-your-vote-important-dates/) and [Florida](https://www.ocfelections.com/vote-by-mail)). The complexity and variability of these regulations render the claim overly broad and misleading.
column7: The claim is cherrypicking as some states do accept the ballots and some do not.

column2: Ivermectin is a treatment for coronavirus.
column5: While some studies suggest Ivermectin may have antiviral properties against SARS-CoV-2, the overall evidence indicates that it has not been proven effective or safe for treating COVID-19. Regulatory agencies, health organizations, and medical associations have not endorsed Ivermectin as a treatment for coronavirus, and its use is not recommended outside of clinical trials. Inconclusive or mixed results from randomized controlled trials, lack of recommended dosages, and insufficient data on interactions with other medications further support the verdict that Ivermectin is not a proven treatment for coronavirus. [Source](https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/ivermectin-cure-coronavirus/) [Source](https://www.fda.gov/safety/medical-product-safety-information/ivermectin-intended-animals-letter-stakeholders-do-not-use-humans-treatment-covid-19)

column2: Sleeping under a mosquito bed net treated (or not treated) with insecticide is ineffective and harmful to human health.
column5: The claim that sleeping under a mosquito bed net treated or not treated with insecticide is ineffective and harmful to human health is refuted. Reputable medical organizations like [World Health Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosquito_net) and [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosquito_net) recommend the use of insecticide-treated bed nets as an effective method for preventing vector-borne diseases like malaria. No documented cases of adverse health effects directly attributed to their use were found, and numerous peer-reviewed studies published after 2015 contradict the claim, confirming the effectiveness of these nets in preventing malaria and other vector-borne diseases.
column7: Sleeping under a mosquito net is effective in preventing man-vector contact

column2: Pogba Has Quit The French National Team Over Macron's Remarks on Islam.

In reality, Pogba remains an active player for the French national team, and there is no official statement from the French Football Federation regarding his status with the national team [Mirror](https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/breaking-man-utd-star-paul-22904740).

column2: The Wire called Durga puja racist and the goddess Durga a sex worker
column5: The claim that The Wire called Durga Puja "racist" and Goddess Durga a "sex worker" is refuted. An investigation revealed that The Wire published an article ["Mahishasura and the Minister"](https://thewire.in/media/fact-check-viral-durga-puja-screenshot) in 2016, which quoted Union Minister Smriti Irani's Lok Sabha speech describing Durga Puja in a certain way, but did not endorse or agree with those views. The Wire's founding editor Siddharth Varadarajan also clarified on Twitter that the article was fabricated and the quote was attributed to Smriti Irani, not The Wire. Therefore, the claim is a misrepresentation of the article.
